_link.title: I can solve projectile problems for objects launched at an angle from ground level

toLevel2.question: What formula gives the horizontal component of the initial velocity for an angled projectile launch?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The horizontal component is found by multiplying the launch speed by the cosine of the launch angle.

distractors.explanation: Sine gives the vertical component, not the horizontal component.
Tangent is the ratio of vertical to horizontal components, not a component itself.
Dividing by cosine does not resolve the velocity into a horizontal component.

toLevel2.question: What formula gives the vertical component of the initial velocity for an angled projectile launch?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The vertical component is found by multiplying the launch speed by the sine of the launch angle.

distractors.explanation: Cosine gives the horizontal component, not the vertical component.
Tangent is not used to resolve the vertical component of velocity.
Dividing by sine does not resolve the velocity into a vertical component.

toLevel2.question: What is the formula for the time of flight of a projectile launched at angle θ from ground level?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The time of flight equals twice the initial vertical component divided by gravitational acceleration.

distractors.explanation: This incorrectly uses the horizontal component; time of flight depends on the vertical component.
This gives the time to reach maximum height, not the total time of flight.
This formula has incorrect dimensions and does not give the time of flight.

toLevel2.question: Which formula gives the maximum height of a projectile launched at angle θ from ground level?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Maximum height is found using the vertical component squared divided by twice the gravitational acceleration.

distractors.explanation: This incorrectly uses the horizontal component; maximum height depends on the vertical component.
This places sin θ in the denominator incorrectly instead of squaring v sin θ in the numerator.
This is the formula for time of flight, not maximum height.

toLevel2.question: Which formula gives the range of a projectile launched at angle θ from ground level?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The range uses the initial speed squared multiplied by sin of twice the angle, divided by g.

distractors.explanation: This uses sin θ instead of sin 2θ, which would give an incorrect range.
This uses cos 2θ instead of sin 2θ, giving the wrong trigonometric function.
This formula is not equivalent to the correct range expression using sin 2θ.

toLevel2.question: For an angled projectile launched from ground level, the time of flight depends on the vertical component of the initial velocity.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The time of flight T = 2v sin θ / g depends only on the vertical component v sin θ and gravity.

distractors.explanation: Students may think the horizontal component affects flight time, but horizontal motion does not influence how long the projectile stays in the air.

toLevel2.question: The horizontal component of velocity changes throughout the flight of an angled projectile (ignoring air resistance).
toLevel2.correctExplanation: With no air resistance, there is no horizontal force, so the horizontal component of velocity remains constant throughout the flight.

distractors.explanation: Students may think gravity affects horizontal motion, but gravity acts only vertically, leaving horizontal velocity unchanged.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about resolving velocity for an angled projectile.
toLevel2.sentence: For a projectile launched at speed v at angle θ, the horizontal component is v {{blank:1}} θ and the vertical component is v {{blank:2}} θ.

1.correctExplanation: The horizontal component uses cosine because it is adjacent to the angle in the velocity triangle.

distractors.explanation: Sine gives the vertical component, not the horizontal component.
Tangent is the ratio of opposite to adjacent, not used for resolving components.

2.correctExplanation: The vertical component uses sine because it is opposite to the angle in the velocity triangle.

distractors.explanation: Cosine gives the horizontal component, not the vertical component.
Tangent is the ratio of components, not used for resolving individual components.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about projectile flight time.
toLevel2.sentence: The time of flight for a ground-level launch is T = 2v sin θ / {{blank:1}}, which equals twice the time to reach {{blank:2}} height.

1.correctExplanation: Gravitational acceleration g = 9.8 m/s² is the denominator in the time of flight formula.

distractors.explanation: The initial speed v appears in the numerator, not the denominator.
The denominator is g, not 2g; the factor of 2 is in the numerator.

2.correctExplanation: The projectile takes half the total flight time to reach its maximum height, so the full flight is twice that.

distractors.explanation: The minimum height is at the ground; the time to reach maximum height is the relevant half-time.
The total flight time is twice the time to reach the peak, not twice the time to reach average height.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about maximum height.
toLevel2.sentence: At maximum height, the {{blank:1}} component of velocity is zero, while the {{blank:2}} component remains unchanged.

1.correctExplanation: At the peak, the vertical velocity has been reduced to zero by gravity before reversing direction.

distractors.explanation: The horizontal component stays constant throughout the flight; it is the vertical that reaches zero.
The resultant velocity is not zero at the peak because the horizontal component persists.

2.correctExplanation: With no air resistance, there is no horizontal force, so the horizontal velocity stays constant.

distractors.explanation: The vertical component is zero at maximum height, not unchanged.
The resultant velocity changes because the vertical component changes; only the horizontal remains constant.

toLevel3.question: Why does increasing the launch angle beyond 45° decrease the range of a ground-level projectile?
toLevel3.correct: The horizontal velocity component decreases more than the flight time increases
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Above 45°, the gain in flight time from a larger vertical component does not compensate for the reduced horizontal velocity.

distractors.answer: Gravity becomes stronger at steeper angles of projection
distractors.explanation: Gravitational acceleration is constant regardless of launch angle.

distractors.answer: The projectile always reaches the same maximum height above 45°
distractors.explanation: Maximum height continues to increase above 45°; it is the range that decreases.

distractors.answer: Air resistance increases significantly at higher launch angles
distractors.explanation: This analysis ignores air resistance; the effect is purely due to component resolution.

toLevel3.question: Why is 45° the launch angle that produces the maximum range for a ground-level projectile?
toLevel3.correct: Because sin(2θ) reaches its maximum value of 1 when θ = 45°
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Since R = v² sin(2θ)/g, the range is maximised when sin(2θ) = sin(90°) = 1, which occurs at θ = 45°.

distractors.answer: Because the vertical and horizontal forces are equal at 45°
distractors.explanation: Forces do not change with launch angle; only the velocity components are equal at 45°.

distractors.answer: Because air resistance is minimised at a 45° launch angle
distractors.explanation: This analysis ignores air resistance; the maximum range at 45° is a geometric result.

distractors.answer: Because gravity has no effect on the projectile at 45°
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts equally on the projectile regardless of the launch angle.

toLevel3.question: Why does the horizontal velocity remain constant throughout an angled projectile's flight (ignoring air resistance)?
toLevel3.correct: Because no horizontal force acts on the projectile after launch
toLevel3.correctExplanation: With no air resistance, gravity is the only force and it acts vertically, so horizontal velocity is unchanged.

distractors.answer: Because the initial kinetic energy is conserved horizontally
distractors.explanation: Energy conservation is valid but does not directly explain constant horizontal velocity; the absence of force does.

distractors.answer: Because the horizontal and vertical motions cancel out
distractors.explanation: The two components are independent; they do not cancel each other.

distractors.answer: Because the projectile accelerates equally in all directions
distractors.explanation: Acceleration due to gravity acts only downward, not in all directions.

toLevel3.question: A ball launched at 30° and another at 60° with the same speed will have the same range. Why?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Complementary angles produce the same value of sin(2θ), so the range formula gives the same result.

distractors.answer: Because both projectiles reach the same maximum height
distractors.explanation: Complementary angles give different heights; the 60° launch reaches a greater height.

distractors.answer: Because both projectiles have the same time of flight
distractors.explanation: The 60° launch has a longer flight time; the ranges match due to sin(2θ) symmetry.

distractors.answer: Because gravity affects both projectiles in the same way
distractors.explanation: While gravity is the same, the equal range is specifically due to the sin(2θ) relationship.

toLevel3.question: What does the trajectory of an angled projectile look like, and why?
toLevel3.correct: A parabola, because constant horizontal velocity combines with accelerating vertical motion
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The combination of uniform horizontal motion and uniformly accelerated vertical motion produces a parabolic path.

distractors.answer: A straight line, because velocity is constant throughout the flight
distractors.explanation: Velocity changes direction due to gravity, so the path curves into a parabola.

distractors.answer: A circular arc, because gravity curves the path at a constant radius
distractors.explanation: Gravity produces a constant acceleration, not constant curvature, so the path is parabolic.

distractors.answer: An ellipse, because the projectile follows an orbital path around Earth
distractors.explanation: For typical projectile speeds, the path is parabolic, not elliptical.

toLevel3.question: Why is the time to reach maximum height exactly half the total time of flight for a ground-level launch?
toLevel3.correct: Because the upward and downward journeys are symmetrical under constant gravity
toLevel3.correctExplanation: With no air resistance and a ground-level launch, the parabolic trajectory is symmetric, so ascent time equals descent time.

distractors.answer: Because the projectile decelerates on the way up and stops completely
distractors.explanation: The vertical velocity reaches zero at the peak but the horizontal component persists; symmetry is the key reason.

distractors.answer: Because gravity only acts during the first half of the flight
distractors.explanation: Gravity acts throughout the entire flight, not just during the ascent.

distractors.answer: Because the horizontal velocity doubles during the descent phase
distractors.explanation: Horizontal velocity remains constant throughout; symmetry explains the equal times.

toLevel3.question: Complementary launch angles (such as 30° and 60°) produce the same range when launched at the same speed from ground level.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Complementary angles satisfy sin(2θ) = sin(2(90° - θ)), so R = v² sin(2θ)/g is the same for both.

distractors.explanation: Students may think different angles always produce different ranges, but the sin(2θ) symmetry means complementary angles yield equal ranges.

toLevel3.prompt: Explain the symmetry of complementary angles in projectile motion.
toLevel3.sentence: Angles of 25° and {{blank:1}}° are complementary and produce the same range because sin(2 × 25°) equals sin({{blank:2}}°).

distractors.explanation: 75° is not the complement of 25°; the complement is 90° - 25° = 65°.
55° is not the complement of 25°; the complement is 90° - 25° = 65°.
50° is 2 × 25°, which is the same value; the paired angle is 130° = 2 × 65°.
150° would correspond to a 75° launch, not the complement of 25°.

toLevel3.prompt: Explain why the projectile path is a parabola.
toLevel3.sentence: The trajectory is parabolic because horizontal displacement increases {{blank:1}} with time while vertical displacement changes {{blank:2}} due to gravity.

1.correctExplanation: With constant horizontal velocity, horizontal displacement is proportional to time (x = vx × t).

distractors.explanation: Horizontal displacement grows linearly, not exponentially, since horizontal velocity is constant.
Horizontal displacement grows linearly; it is the vertical displacement that has a quadratic component.

2.correctExplanation: Vertical displacement follows y = vy t - ½gt², which is a quadratic function of time.

distractors.explanation: Vertical displacement has a quadratic term due to gravitational acceleration, not just a linear term.
The vertical displacement is quadratic in time, not cubic; constant acceleration gives a t² dependence.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the statement about maximum range.
toLevel3.sentence: The maximum range for a ground-level projectile occurs at {{blank:1}}° because this angle maximises the product of horizontal velocity and {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: At 45°, sin(2θ) = sin(90°) = 1, which is its maximum possible value.

distractors.explanation: At 30°, sin(60°) = 0.87, which is less than the maximum of 1 at 45°.
At 60°, sin(120°) = 0.87, which is less than the maximum of 1 at 45°.

2.correctExplanation: Range equals horizontal velocity multiplied by time of flight (R = vx × T), and 45° optimises this product.

distractors.explanation: Range depends on the product of horizontal velocity and flight time, not maximum height directly.
Acceleration due to gravity is constant and does not change with angle; the product that is optimised involves flight time.

toLevel4.question: A ball is kicked at 20 m/s at 35° to the horizontal. What is the horizontal component of its initial velocity?

distractors.explanation: This is the vertical component (v sin 35°), not the horizontal component.
This is the total launch speed, not the resolved horizontal component.
This would be v cos 45°, using the wrong angle of 45° instead of 35°.

toLevel4.question: A projectile is launched at 30 m/s at 45° from ground level. What is its time of flight? (g = 9.8 m/s²)

distractors.explanation: This is the time to reach maximum height (half the total flight time), not the full flight time.
This would result from using the full speed instead of the vertical component in the formula.
This would result from dividing by 2g instead of g in the time of flight formula.

toLevel4.question: A projectile is launched at 25 m/s at 60° from ground level. What is its maximum height? (g = 9.8 m/s²)

distractors.explanation: This results from using v²/(2g) without resolving the vertical component, ignoring the angle.
This results from forgetting to divide by 2 in the maximum height formula.
This results from using (v cos θ)² / (2g), which incorrectly uses the horizontal component.

toLevel4.question: A football is kicked at 15 m/s at 30° from ground level. What is the range of the kick? (g = 9.8 m/s²)

distractors.explanation: This results from using sin 30° instead of sin 60° in the range formula.
This results from using v²/g without the sin(2θ) factor.
This results from doubling the correct range, perhaps confusing range with twice the range.

toLevel4.question: A projectile is launched at 10 m/s at 40°. What is its vertical component of initial velocity?

distractors.explanation: This is the horizontal component (v cos 40°), not the vertical component.
This would be v sin 30°, using the wrong angle of 30° instead of 40°.
This would be v sin 57°, using an incorrect angle value.

toLevel4.question: A ball is launched at 24 m/s at 45° from ground level. What is the range? (g = 9.8 m/s²)

distractors.explanation: This results from using v² sin θ / g instead of v² sin(2θ) / g.
This results from using v² sin(2θ) / (2g), incorrectly adding a factor of 2 in the denominator.
This results from using v² sin 60° / g, applying the wrong double angle.

toLevel4.question: A javelin is thrown at 18 m/s at 55°. What is its time of flight? (g = 9.8 m/s²)

distractors.explanation: This is the time to reach maximum height (half the total flight time), not the full flight time.
This results from using the full speed (18 m/s) instead of v sin θ in the formula.
This results from using v cos 55° instead of v sin 55° in the time of flight formula.

toLevel4.prompt: Calculate the velocity components for a projectile launched at 20 m/s at 35°.
toLevel4.sentence: The horizontal component is 20 cos 35° = {{blank:1}} m/s and the vertical component is 20 sin 35° = {{blank:2}} m/s.

distractors.explanation: 11.5 m/s is v sin 35°, the vertical component, not the horizontal component.
14.1 m/s would be 20 cos 45°, using the wrong angle.
16.4 m/s is v cos 35°, the horizontal component, not the vertical component.
14.1 m/s would be 20 sin 45°, using the wrong angle.

toLevel4.prompt: Calculate the time of flight and range for a ball launched at 20 m/s at 35°. (g = 9.8 m/s²)
toLevel4.sentence: The time of flight is 2 × 11.5 / 9.8 = {{blank:1}} s, and the range is 16.4 × 2.34 = {{blank:2}} m.

distractors.explanation: 1.17 s is half the flight time (time to reach maximum height), not the total.
3.35 s would result from using the full speed (20 m/s) instead of the vertical component.
This would result from using the vertical component instead of the horizontal component for range.
This would result from using the full speed 20 m/s instead of the horizontal component.

toLevel4.prompt: Calculate the maximum height for a projectile launched at 30 m/s at 45°. (g = 9.8 m/s²)
toLevel4.sentence: vy = 30 sin 45° = {{blank:1}} m/s, so the maximum height is (21.2)² / (2 × 9.8) = {{blank:2}} m.

distractors.explanation: 15.0 m/s would be 30 × sin 30°, using the wrong angle.
26.0 m/s would be 30 × sin 60°, using the wrong angle.
This results from using v² / (2g) = 900 / 19.6, forgetting to resolve the vertical component.
This results from using (v sin θ)² / (4g), incorrectly doubling the denominator.

toLevel5.question: A golfer hits a ball at 40 m/s at 50° from ground level. A tree 150 m away is 20 m tall. Does the ball clear the tree? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
toLevel5.correct: No, the ball is at about 12.0 m height at 150 m, which is below the 20 m tree
toLevel5.correctExplanation: vx = 25.7 m/s, so the time to reach 150 m is t = 150/25.7 = 5.83 s. Height: y = 30.6(5.83) - 4.9(5.83)² = 178.4 - 166.5 = 12.0 m, which is below the 20 m tree.

distractors.answer: Yes, because the maximum height of 47.9 m far exceeds the 20 m tree
distractors.explanation: Maximum height occurs at the midpoint of the range, not at 150 m; you must calculate the height at the tree's position.

distractors.answer: No, because the ball lands before it reaches the 150 m mark
distractors.explanation: The range is about 160.8 m, so the ball is still airborne at 150 m; it just isn't high enough.

distractors.answer: Yes, because the ball is at about 30 m height when it reaches the tree
distractors.explanation: This overestimates the height; the correct calculation gives approximately 12.0 m at 150 m.

toLevel5.question: Two projectiles are launched from ground level at the same speed of 35 m/s but at 40° and 50° respectively. Compare their ranges and maximum heights.
toLevel5.correct: They have the same range, but the 50° projectile reaches a greater maximum height
toLevel5.correctExplanation: 40° and 50° are complementary, so sin(80°) = sin(100°) and ranges are equal. The 50° launch has a larger vertical component, so it reaches a greater height.

distractors.answer: They have the same range and the same maximum height throughout their flight
distractors.explanation: While ranges are equal, the steeper angle produces a greater maximum height.

distractors.answer: The 40° projectile has both a greater range and a greater maximum height
distractors.explanation: Complementary angles give equal ranges; the steeper angle gives greater height.

distractors.answer: The 50° projectile has a greater range and a greater maximum height
distractors.explanation: Complementary angles give equal ranges; only the height differs.

toLevel5.question: A student calculates the range of a projectile launched at 50 m/s at 30° using R = v² sin θ / g and gets 127.6 m. Identify and correct the error.
toLevel5.correct: The student used sin θ instead of sin(2θ); the correct range is 220.9 m
toLevel5.correctExplanation: R = v² sin(2θ)/g = 2500 × sin 60° / 9.8 = 2500 × 0.866 / 9.8 = 220.9 m. Using sin 30° = 0.5 gives the wrong answer of 127.6 m.

distractors.answer: The student forgot to square the velocity; correct range is 441.8 m
distractors.explanation: The student did square v (50² = 2500); the error is using sin θ instead of sin(2θ).

distractors.answer: The student used radians instead of degrees for the angle calculation
distractors.explanation: Using radians for 30 gives sin(30 rad), which is not 0.5; the actual error is sin θ vs sin(2θ).

distractors.answer: The student should have divided by 2g instead of g in the formula
distractors.explanation: The range formula uses g in the denominator, not 2g; the error is in the angle term.

toLevel5.question: A projectile is launched at 22 m/s at 50°. At what time after launch does the projectile first reach a height of 10 m? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Using y = vy t - ½gt²: 10 = 16.85t - 4.9t². Rearranging: 4.9t² - 16.85t + 10 = 0. Using the quadratic formula: t = (16.85 - √(283.9 - 196))/9.8 = (16.85 - 9.38)/9.8 = 0.76 s.

distractors.explanation: This is the time to reach maximum height (half the flight time), not the time to first reach 10 m.
This is the second time the projectile is at 10 m (on the way down), not the first time on the way up.
This results from incorrectly using the horizontal component instead of the vertical component in the height equation.

toLevel5.question: A projectile launched at 45° has a range of 91.8 m. What is its launch speed? (g = 9.8 m/s²)

distractors.explanation: This confuses the launch speed with the horizontal component; 21.2 m/s is v cos 45° when v = 30 m/s.
This results from doubling the correct speed, perhaps from an error in rearranging the formula.
This results from taking the square root incorrectly or using half the correct value.

toLevel5.question: Analyse how doubling the launch speed affects the range and maximum height of a ground-level projectile at the same angle.
toLevel5.correct: Range quadruples and maximum height quadruples
toLevel5.correctExplanation: R = v² sin(2θ)/g and H = (v sin θ)²/(2g) both depend on v², so doubling v multiplies both by 4.

distractors.answer: Range doubles and maximum height doubles as well
distractors.explanation: Both formulas contain v², so doubling v gives a factor of 4, not 2.

distractors.answer: Range quadruples but maximum height only doubles
distractors.explanation: Both range and height contain v², so both quadruple when speed doubles.

distractors.answer: Range doubles and maximum height quadruples instead
distractors.explanation: Both quantities depend on v², so both quadruple by the same factor.

toLevel5.question: A ball launched at 12 m/s at 25° has a maximum height of 1.31 m but a ball launched at 12 m/s at 65° has a maximum height of 6.03 m. Evaluate why the heights differ despite identical ranges.
toLevel5.correct: The steeper angle directs more velocity vertically, increasing height but keeping range equal via sin(2θ) symmetry
toLevel5.correctExplanation: At 65°, vy = 12 sin 65° = 10.88 m/s vs vy = 12 sin 25° = 5.07 m/s at 25°. Greater vy gives greater H, but sin(50°) = sin(130°) keeps ranges equal.

distractors.answer: The 65° launch has more total energy, which increases the maximum height
distractors.explanation: Both launches have the same speed, so kinetic energy is identical; the distribution between components differs.

distractors.answer: Gravity acts differently on steeper launches, allowing greater height
distractors.explanation: Gravity is constant; the different heights result from different vertical velocity components.

distractors.answer: The heights should be equal because the ranges are equal for complementary angles
distractors.explanation: Only range is equal for complementary angles; maximum height depends on (v sin θ)² which differs.

toLevel5.question: A student claims that a projectile launched at 60° spends more time in the air than one launched at 30° at the same speed, so it must travel further. Evaluate this reasoning.
toLevel5.correct: The reasoning is flawed: longer flight time is offset by a smaller horizontal velocity, giving equal range
toLevel5.correctExplanation: At 60°, flight time is longer but vx is smaller. At 30°, flight time is shorter but vx is larger. These effects exactly compensate, giving equal range.

distractors.answer: The reasoning is correct: more time in the air always means greater range
distractors.explanation: Range depends on both flight time and horizontal velocity; they trade off for complementary angles.

distractors.answer: The reasoning is flawed: both launches have equal flight time
distractors.explanation: The flight times are not equal; the 60° launch does have a longer flight time.

distractors.answer: The reasoning is correct: the 60° launch also has a larger horizontal velocity
distractors.explanation: The 60° launch has a smaller horizontal velocity (v cos 60° < v cos 30°).

toLevel5.prompt: Analyse the effect of changing angle on range for a fixed speed.
toLevel5.sentence: For a 35 m/s launch, changing the angle from 40° to 50° keeps the range at {{blank:1}} m because both angles produce sin(2θ) = {{blank:2}}.

distractors.explanation: 91.8 m would be the range at 45° for a 30 m/s launch, not a 35 m/s launch at 40° or 50°.
This rounds up to an incorrect value; the precise calculation gives 123.1 m.

2.correctExplanation: sin(80°) = sin(100°) = 0.985, confirming both angles yield the same range factor.

distractors.explanation: 0.866 is sin 60°, which corresponds to 30° or 60° launches, not 40° or 50°.
sin(2θ) = 1 only when θ = 45°; at 40° and 50°, sin(2θ) = 0.985.

toLevel5.prompt: Compare two complementary angle launches at 25 m/s.
toLevel5.sentence: At 60°, the maximum height is {{blank:1}} m, while at 30° it is only {{blank:2}} m, even though both have the same range of 55.2 m.

distractors.explanation: This results from using v²/(2g) without resolving the vertical component.
This is the maximum height for the 30° launch, not the 60° launch.
23.9 m is the maximum height for the 60° launch, not the 30° launch.
This is not the correct value; (25 sin 30°)²/(2g) = 7.97 m.
